choices.text: G4 P1 L1 A2
G4 P3 L1 A2
G3 P1 L1 A2
G3 P3 L1 A2

questions.text: A middle-aged woman came to OPD with a twin pregnancy. She already had 2 first trimester abortions and she has a 3-year-old female child who was born at the end of the 9th month of gestation. Which of the following is her accurate representation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. G4 P1 L1 A2

 

Explanation:

 

Determining the Parity Index/ Obstetric Formula

 

  • 2 formulas

 

1. G __ P __ L __ A ___

 

  • Gravida (G): The number of times a woman has conceived including the present pregnancy irrespective of the gestational age or the outcome.
  • Para (P): The number of times a pregnancy has crossed the period of viability (taken as 28 weeks for all practical purposes) EXCLUDING the present pregnancy.
  • Living (L): The total number of living children the woman has.
  • Abortion (A): The total number of times the pregnancy has resulted in an abortion/ pregnancy has not crossed the period of viability.

 

In this patient, this is her 4th pregnancy, so she is G4; she has 1 pregnancy who was born at term, so she is P1; she has 2 abortions so she is A2 and she has 1 living child so she is L1.

 

Hence she is G4P11A2

 

*** IMPORTANT: A Twin pregnancy which has crossed the period of viability is considered as Para 1 NOT Para 2. But if it results in 2 living children it will be Live 2. ***

 

2. P A-B-C-D (A: term; B: preterm; C: abortions; D: Living)

 

  • This is another way to write the formula.           

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gravida (G): The number of times a woman has conceived including the present pregnancy irrespective of the gestational age or the outcome.
  • Para (P): The number of times a pregnancy has crossed the period of viability (taken as 28 weeks for all practical purposes) EXCLUDING the present pregnancy.
  • Living (L): The total number of living children the woman has.
  • Abortion (A): The total number of times the pregnancy has resulted in an abortion/ pregnancy has not crossed the period of viability.

 

Ref: Page 160, William’s Obstetrics; 25th edition

choices.text: It excludes the present pregnancy.
It includes all pregnancies that have crossed the period of viability.
It is taken as 2 in case of a previous twin pregnancy.
It does not include spontaneous abortions.

questions.text: All are true regarding the definition of para except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is taken as 2 in case of a previous twin pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s Discuss all Options

 

  • Option A: It excludes the present pregnancy: Para (P) is the number of times a pregnancy has crossed the period of viability (taken as 28 weeks for all practical purposes) EXCLUDING the present pregnancy
  • Option B: It includes all pregnancies that have crossed the period of viability: Para (P) is the number of times a pregnancy has crossed the period of viability (taken as 28 weeks for all practical purposes) EXCLUDING the present pregnancy
  • Option C: It is taken as 2 in case of a previous twin pregnancy. This is wrong. In a previous twin pregnancy, P is 1 as it is the number of pregnancies that are counted and not the number of fetuses.
  • Option D: It does not include spontaneous abortions: Spontaneous or induced abortions are denoted by A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The obstetric formula is written as:

 

  • 2 formulas

 

1. G __ P __ L __ A ___

 

  • Gravida (G): The number of times a woman has conceived including the present pregnancy irrespective of the gestational age or the outcome.
  • Para (P): The number of times a pregnancy has crossed the period of viability (taken as 28 weeks for all practical purposes) EXCLUDING the present pregnancy.
  • Living (L): The total number of living children the woman has.
  • Abortion (A): The total number of times the pregnancy has resulted in an abortion/ pregnancy has not crossed the period of viability.

 

*** IMPORTANT: A Twin pregnancy which has crossed the period of viability is considered as Para 1 NOT Para 2. But if it results in 2 living children it will be Live 2. ***

 

2. P A-B-C-D (A: term; B: preterm; C: abortions; D: Living)

 

  • This is another way to write the formula.

 

Ref: Page 160, William’s Obstetrics; 25th edition

choices.text: Fundal grip
Lateral grip
1st pelvic grip
2nd pelvic grip

questions.text: Identify the examination being done in the image below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lateral grip

 

Explanation:

 

The maneuver shown in the image is the Lateral Grip or Leopold’s 2nd maneuver

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leopold Maneuvers:

 

Leopold in 1894 described 4 abdominal maneuvers to diagnose fetal presentation. These maneuvers may be difficult in

 

  • Obesity
  • Oligohydramnios and polyhydramnios
  • Anterior placenta
    1. Fundal grip (A): to assess which fetal pole (cephalic or podalic) occupies the fundus. The breech gives the sensation of a large nodular mass; the head feel hard, round and mobile
    2. The Lateral grip (B): determines the side of the back (hard, resistant) and the limbs (numerous, small irregular mobile parts)
    3. The 1st pelvic grip (3rd maneuver aka Pawlik grip - C): determining fetal presentation.
    4. The 2nd pelvic grip (4th maneuver - D): determines the degree of descent. This maneuver is done facing the feet of the patient and trying to approximate the hands of the examiner. IF the hands approximate; the head has not descended into the pelvis. If the hands diverge, the head has descended into the pelvis.

 

 

Ref: Page 424, William’s Obstetrics; 25th edition

choices.text: Adding 9 months and 7 days to the LMP
Adding 38 weeks to the LMP
Adding 280 days to the LMP
Subtracting 3 months and adding 7 days to the LMP

questions.text: All the following methods can be used to calculate the EDD except:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Adding 38 weeks to the LMP

 

Explanation:

 

Calculating the EDD:

 

  • Normal duration of pregnancy: 280 days (40 weeks); hence Option B is incorrect. To arrive at the EDD, we add 280 days or 40 weeks to the LMP.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Calculating the EDD: Naegele’s formula. To the LMP (1st day of the last menstrual day
    • Add 9 months + 7 days
    • Subtract 3 months and add 7 days
    • For IVF Pregnancies: add 38 weeks to the date of the embryo transfer

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Calculating the EDD: Naegele’s formula. To the LMP (1st day of the last menstrual day)
    • Add 9 months + 7 days
    • Subtract 3 months and add 7 days
    • For IVF Pregnancies: add 38 weeks to the date of the embryo transfer
  • Remember the EDD falls at 40 weeks (280 days) from the LMP
  • Dating the pregnancy: If discrepancy in dates/ unsure of LMP; the best way to determine the dating is by ULTRASOUND
    • 1st trimester CRL: most accurate (till 14 weeks)
    • BPD in the 2nd trimester

 

Ref: Page no 168, William’s Obstetrics; 25th edition

choices.text: 200 Kcal
300 Kcal
500 Kcal
No extra calories

questions.text: A primigravida was given dietary advice in the 2nd trimester. What should be the extra calorie intake?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. 300 Kcal

 

Explanation:

 

  • Pregnancy requires a total additional of 80,000 Kcal; mostly in the latter half
  • An average caloric increase of 300 Kcal/ day recommended
  • If we divide this trimester wise,
    • 0Kcal/ day in 1st trimester
    • 340Kcal/ day in 2nd trimester
    • 452Kcal/ day in 3rd trimesters

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pregnancy requires a total additional of 80,000 Kcal; mostly in the latter half
  • An average caloric increase of 300 Kcal/ day recommended
  • If we divide this trimester wise,
    • 0Kcal/ day in 1st trimester
    • 340Kcal/ day in 2nd trimester
    • 452Kcal/ day in 3rd trimesters
  • If a question is asked regarding extra calorie in the 1st trimester, the answer will be NO Additional Requirement.
  • Women who breastfeed require approximately 500 additional kcal/day; beyond what is usually recommended for non-pregnant women
  • RDA of proteins in pregnancy: 60 – 65g/ day (increase by 15g/ day)

 

Ref: Page no 168, William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: 0.5 kg / week
0.4 kg / week
0.3 kg / week
0.2 kg / week

questions.text: A 25-year Primi gravida is at 24 weeks pregnancy. Her pre-pregnancy BMI was 22. She is concerned she hasn’t been gaining enough weight during pregnancy. What should her ideal weight gain (kg)/ week be?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. 0.4 kg/ week

 

Explanation

 

  • In a woman with normal BMI, the ideal weight gain is 0.4kg/ week in the 2nd and 3rd trimester

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ideal weight gain in pregnancy

 

 

Ref: Page no 170, William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: Identifying potential high-risk factors like Hypertension, anemia, diabetes etc
Starting women on folic acid preconceptionally
Assessing for genetic diseases and offering counselling
Offering rubella immunization post conception

questions.text: All are components of pre-conceptional counselling except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Offering rubella immunization post conception

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s Discuss all Options:

 

  • Option A: Identify high risk factors: Diabetes (HBA1C), HTN, Epilepsy, Thyroid disorders (TSH), Anemia (Hb)
  • Option B: Pre-conceptional Folic Acid (0.4 mg/ day (400mcg per day)  to low risk; 4 mg/ day to high risk for neural tube defects - NTD). Women at high risk for NTD are
    • H/o previous baby with NTD
    • Pre-gestational Diabetes Mellitus
    • Folic acid deficiency
    • Obesity
    • Epilepsy/ on Antiepileptic Drugs (AED)
  • Option C: Assess for genetic diseases (h/o sickle cell ds, cystic fibrosis, thalassemia etc.)
  • Option D: Immunization status: Rubella; if unimmunized or status unknown, Rubella vaccination is to be given with advice to avoid conception till 1 month following vaccination as it is a live vaccine with potential teratogenic side effects to the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Components of pre-conceptional counseling:

 

  • Identify high risk factors: Diabetes (HBA1C), HTN, Epilepsy, Thyroid disorders (TSH), Anemia (Hb)
  • Immunization status: Rubella; if unimmunized or status unknown, Rubella vaccination is to be given with advice to avoid conception till 1 month following vaccination as it is a live vaccine with potential teratogenic side effects to the fetus.
  • Check the BMI and advise optimization prior to planning pregnancy
  • Stop/change any teratogenic drug (antiepileptic, warfarin, ACE inhibitor, ARB)
  • Pre-conceptional Folic Acid (0.4 mg/ day (400mcg per day)  to low risk; 4 mg/ day to high risk for neural tube defects - NTD). Women at high risk for NTD are
    • H/o previous baby with NTD
    • Pre-gestational Diabetes Mellitus
    • Folic acid deficiency
    • Obesity
    • Epilepsy/ on Antiepileptic Drugs (AED)
  • Assess for genetic diseases (h/o sickle cell ds, cystic fibrosis, thalassemia etc.)
  • Smoking, alcohol, drug abuse – Advise to STOP

 

Ref: Page no,172, 147 Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: At least 4 visits, including the registration visit
At least 4 visits excluding the registration visit
At least 8 visits with 1 in the 1st trimester, 2 in the 2nd trimester and 5 in the 3rd trimester
At least 8 visits, 2 in the 1st trimester, 2 in the 2nd trimester and 4 in the 3rd trimester

questions.text: What is the WHO recommendation for Antenatal Visits?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. At least 8 visits with 1 in the 1st trimester, 2 in the 2nd trimester and 5 in the 3rd trimester

 

Explanation:

 

As per the WHO, 8 contact visits are recommended in the antenatal period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Protocol for Antenatal Visits

 

  1. MOHFW (Indian guidelines)
    • At least4 visits including the first (Registration visit) – Minimum requirement
    • Suggested schedule
      • 1st Visit: Within 12 weeks
      • 2nd Visit: 14 – 26 weeks
      • 3rd Visit: 28 – 34 weeks
      • 4th visit: 36 weeks – term
  2. WHO (2016): 8 visits.
    • 1st Trimester:
      • Contact 1: upto 12 weeks
    • 2nd Trimester
      • Contact 2 (20 weeks) & Contact 3 (26 weeks)
    • 3rd Trimester       
      • Contact 4 (30 week), Contact 5 (34 weeks), contact 6 (36 weeks), contact 7 (38 weeks) & Contact 8 (40 weeks)

 

Ideally (& as per ACOG): once every month till 28 weeks, every 2 weeks till 36 weeks and then weekly till 40 weeks: So total of 12 – 14 visits.

 

Ref: WHO Recommendations on Antenatal care for a positive pregnancy experience , MOHFW guidelines and Williams Obstetrics Pg 164 ,  25th edition

choices.text: 200 KCal
300 KCal
500 KCcal
No extra calories

questions.text: A primigravida was given dietary advice in the first trimester. What should be the extra calorie intake in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. No extra calories

 

Explanation:

 

  • In the 1st trimester of pregnancy, no additional calorie requirement is required

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pregnancy requires a total additional of 80,000 Kcal; mostly in the latter half
  • An average caloric increase of 300 Kcal/ day recommended
  • If we divide this trimester wise,
    • 0Kcal/ day in 1st trimester
    • 340Kcal/ day in 2nd trimester
    • 452Kcal/ day in 3rd trimesters
  • If a question is asked regarding extra calorie in the 1st trimester, the answer will be NO Additional Requirement.
  • Women who breastfeed require approximately 500 additional kcal/day; beyond what is usually recommended for non-pregnant women
  • RDA of proteins in pregnancy: 60 – 65g/ day (increase by 15g/ day)

 

Ref: Page no 168, William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: Pelvic grip
Pawlick grip
Fundal grip
Umbilical grip

questions.text: Identify the grip in the picture used for checking ballotability of head?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pawlick grip

 

Explanation

 

  • The image shows the #rd Leopold maneuver; also called the 1st pelvic grip; also called the Pawlik grip.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There are 4 Leopold Maneuvers:

 

  1. Fundal grip (A): to assess which fetal pole (cephalic or podalic) occupies the fundus. The breech gives the sensation of a large nodular mass; the head feel hard, round and mobile
  2. The Lateral grip (B): determines the side of the back (hard, resistant) and the limbs (numerous, small irregular mobile parts)
  3. The 1st pelvic grip (3rd maneuver aka Pawlik grip - C): determining fetal presentation.
  4. The 2nd pelvic grip (4th maneuver - D): determines the degree of descent. This maneuver is done facing the feet of the patient and trying to approximate the hands of the examiner. IF the hands approximate; the head has not descended into the pelvis. If the hands diverge, the head has descended into the pelvis.

 

 

Ref: Page 424, William’s Obstetrics; 25th edition

choices.text: 9th January
16th September
16th October
9th October

questions.text: A patient presented at 20 weeks of gestation. The patient’s LMP was 9th January. What will be the estimated date of delivery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 16th October

 

Explanation:

 

If we use Nagele’s rule for this patient, adding 9 months and 7 days ti 9th Jan will give us 16th October.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calculating the EDD:

 

  • Normal duration of pregnancy: 280 days (40 weeks)
  • Calculating the EDD: Naegele’s formula. To the LMP (1st day of the last menstrual day
    • Add 9 months + 7 days
    • Subtract 3 months and add 7 days
    • For IVF Pregnancies: add 38 weeks to the date of the embryo transfer
  • Dating the pregnancy: If discrepancy in dates/ unsure of LMP; the best way to determine the dating is by ULTRASOUND
    • 1st trimester CRL: most accurate (till 14 weeks)
    • BPD in the 2nd trimester

 

Ref: Page no 168, William’s Obstetrics; 25th edition

choices.text: At 6 weeks of pregnancy
At 8 weeks of pregnancy
At least 3 months prior to conception
At least 6 months prior to conception

questions.text: Use of folic acid to prevent neural tube defects should be best initiated:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. At least 3 months prior to conception

 

Explanation

 

Folic acid should ideally be started 3 months pre-conceptionally and continued till the 1st 3 months of pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folic acid supplementation in pregnancy

 

  • Lowers the risk of developing NTDs
  • Daily intake of 400 mcg of folic acid in the periconceptional period can prevent NTDs
  • The neural tube has already closed by 6 weeks hence it should be started much before this time

 

Ref: Page 169, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 500 mcg folic acid and 60 mg iron weekly
500 mcg folic acid and 60 mg iron daily
400 mcg folic acid and 100 mg iron daily
400 mcg folic acid and 60 mg daily

questions.text: Iron and Folic acid supplementation dose for pregnant women in Anemia Mukt Bharat?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 500 mcg folic acid and 60 mg iron daily

 

As per the National Health Program “Anemia Mukt Bharat” started in 2018:

 

Pregnant and Lactating women (of 0-6 months child): Should receive:

  • Daily, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet starting from the fourth month of pregnancy (that is from the second trimester)
  • Continued throughout pregnancy (minimum 180 days during pregnancy) and
  • To be continued for 180 days, post-partum
  • Each tablet containing 60 mg elemental Iron + 500 mcg Folic Acid, sugar-coated and red-colour.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As per the National Health Program “Anemia Mukt Bharat” started in 2018:

Pregnant and Lactating women (of 0-6 months child): Should receive:

  • Daily, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet starting from the fourth month of pregnancy (that is from the second trimester)
  • Continued throughout pregnancy (minimum 180 days during pregnancy) and
  • To be continued for 180 days, post-partum
  • Each tablet containing 60 mg elemental Iron + 500 mcg Folic Acid, sugar-coated and red-colour.

 

Ref: https://anemiamuktbharat.info/

choices.text: Diagnosis of fetal anomalies
Establishment of a due date
Assessment of maternal health
Determination of fetal sex

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents for her first prenatal visit. What is the primary goal of the initial prenatal visit?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Assessment of maternal health

 

Explanation: The primary goal of the initial prenatal visit is to assess the health of the mother. This includes obtaining a detailed medical history, performing a physical examination, and conducting various tests to evaluate maternal health and identify any potential risks or medical conditions that may affect the pregnancy.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A: Diagnosis of fetal anomalies is done initially at 11-14 weeks and then again at 18-22 weeks (Level 2/ anomaly scan)
  • Option B: Establishment of a due date: This is done in the initial visit but is not the primary goal
  • Option D: Determination of fetal sex is not important and is not legal in India

 

Educational Objective: The 1st antenatal visit is primarily done to assess the maternal health and give basic antenatal advice

 

Ref: Page no 161, William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: Glucose tolerance test
Urinalysis
Rubella titer
Pap smear

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman is scheduled for her first prenatal visit. Which of the following laboratory tests is typically performed at the initial prenatal visit to screen for underlying health conditions and to provide a baseline for comparison throughout pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Urinalysis

 

Explanation: Urinalysis is typically performed at the initial prenatal visit to screen for underlying health conditions and to provide a baseline for comparison throughout pregnancy. It can help detect conditions such as urinary tract infections, proteinuria, or glucose in the urine, which may indicate gestational diabetes or other health concerns.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A: Glucose tolerance test is generally performed between 24-28 weeks
  • Option C: Rubella antibody titers are checked prior to conception; if IgG is negative vaccine should be given before planning pregnancy
  • Option D: Pap smear is generally not performed in pregnancy and has no bearing on the overall maternal health.

 

Ref: Page no 163 , William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: Non-stress test (NST)
Amniocentesis
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening
Fetal kick counts

questions.text: A pregnant woman had a previous baby with history of neural tube defect. Which routine antenatal screening test should be offered?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening

 

Explanation:

 

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening is a routine antenatal test typically offered around 15-20 weeks of gestation to assess the risk of neural tube defects and other fetal anomalies. Abnormal AFP levels may indicate the need for further diagnostic tests, such as amniocentesis.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. NST: This is a test of antepartum fetal assessment and is usually done after 32 weeks
  • Option B. Amniocentesis: Diagnostic amniocentesis is usually done for detecting fetal chromosomal anomalies
  • Option D. Fetal kick count: This is a test of antepartum fetal assessment and is advised after 28 weeks

 

Educational Objective: Maternal serum AFP is raised in fetuses with neural tube defects

 

Ref: Page no 192, William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: She should aim to gain as little weight as possible to prevent complications.
She should aim to gain at least 12 kg; regardless of her pre-pregnancy weight.
Weight gain recommendations depend on her pre-pregnancy BMI.
Weight gain is not a concern during pregnancy.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents for her second trimester prenatal visit. She asks about the recommended weight gain during pregnancy. What advice should be given to her?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Weight gain recommendations depend on her pre-pregnancy BMI.

 

Explanation: Weight gain recommendations during pregnancy depend on a woman's pre-pregnancy BMI. For example, women with a normal BMI should aim to gain 10-15 kg, while underweight women may need to gain more, and overweight or obese women may need to gain less. It's important to tailor recommendations to the individual's BMI to optimize maternal and fetal health.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 166, William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: Ultrasound for fetal organ assessment
Routine prenatal testing for genetic disorders
Monitoring fetal growth and well-being
Assessment of maternal blood pressure and urine protein

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman presents for her third trimester prenatal visit. She has no known medical conditions and is experiencing a healthy pregnancy. What should be the focus of antenatal care during the third trimester?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Monitoring fetal growth and well-being

 

Explanation: During the third trimester of pregnancy, the focus of antenatal care includes monitoring fetal growth and well-being, assessing maternal health parameters, and preparing for labor and delivery. Regular assessments of fetal growth, fetal heart rate, and amniotic fluid levels are crucial to ensure the well-being of both the mother and the baby.

 

Other options

 

  • Option A: Ultrasound for fetal organ assessment is done between 18-20 weeks (level 2/ anomaly scan)
  • Option B: Routine prenatal testing for genetic disorders is done between 11-14 weeks
  • Option D: Assessment of maternal BP is done at every visit and if high, a urine protein is checked.

 

Ref: Page no 163, William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition
